G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: Jurisdiction and venue are proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19, as the premises are located within the territorial jurisdiction of the Somerville District Court and the claim arises there.

G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 3.proposition: This action seeks damages not exceeding the monetary jurisdiction of the District Court, as permitted by G.L. c. 212, § 3 and G.L. c. 231, § 1.

G.L. c. 231, \u00a7 1.proposition: This action seeks damages not exceeding the monetary jurisdiction of the District Court, as permitted by G.L. c. 212, § 3 and G.L. c. 231, § 1.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, a landlord shall not “directly or indirectly, by any means whatsoever, interfere with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: The statutory covenant is also implied in every lease and tenancy at will under Massachusetts common law.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the common-law implied covenant of quiet enjoyment and then interprets G.L. c. 186, § 14’s statutory quiet enjoyment protection. It states that every tenancy entails an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb quiet enjoyment, but it does not say that the statutory covenant itself is implied in every lease or tenancy at will. Instead, it treats the statute as a separate, expanded statutory remedy built on the common-law covenant, not as a statutory covenant implied into all leases.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy... Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy. … When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’ — words that have little inherent meaning but a rich background in decisional law — it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute.”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.proposition: The statutory covenant is also implied in every lease and tenancy at will under Massachusetts common law.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the implied covenant (or warranty) of quiet enjoyment in the context of constructive eviction, but it does not state or analyze that the *statutory* covenant is implied in every lease or tenancy at will as a matter of Massachusetts common law. The court assumes the existence of an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment and focuses on whether the landlords’ conduct breached it; it does not tie that covenant to the statutory covenant language or make a general doctrinal statement of the breadth claimed in the proposition.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714 (1977.relevant_excerpt: He ruled that the tenants’ implied warranty of quiet enjoyment was violated by late evening and early morning music and disturbances coming from nearby premises which the landlords leased to others for use as a bar or cocktail lounge (lounge)... Our opinions concerning a constructive eviction by an alleged breach of an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment sometimes have stated that the landlord must perform some act with the intent of depriving the tenant of the enjoyment and occupation of the whole or part of the leased premises.

Wesson v. Leone Enterprises, Inc., 437 M.raw_text: Wesson v. Leone Enterprises, Inc., 437 Mass. 708 (2002)
Wesson v. Leone Enterprises, Inc., 437 M.proposition: The statutory covenant is also implied in every lease and tenancy at will under Massachusetts common law.
Wesson v. Leone Enterprises, Inc., 437 M.support_reasoning: The opinion is about abandoning the common-law rule of independent covenants in commercial leases and adopting mutually dependent covenants; it focuses on commercial tenancies, not on statutory covenants in leases generally or tenancies at will. The only discussion of an implied warranty akin to the statutory covenant is a brief, explicit refusal to decide whether to adopt an implied warranty of suitability for commercial premises. The case does not state that the statutory covenant is implied in every lease or tenancy at will under Massachusetts common law.
Wesson v. Leone Enterprises, Inc., 437 M.relevant_excerpt: "We decline to reach the issue whether an implied warranty of suitability, similar to the implied warranty of habitability for residential leases, should be adopted for commercial leases. See Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184, 199 (1973) ('in a rental of any premises for dwelling purposes, under a written or oral lease, for a specified time or at will, there is an implied warranty that the premises are fit for human occupation'). Adopting such a warranty is not necessary to the adoption of a dependent covenants rule and, as noted, raises a different set of policy issues and considerations in the commercial context."

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).proposition: The statutory covenant is also implied in every lease and tenancy at will under Massachusetts common law.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).support_reasoning: The opinion describes G. L. c. 186, § 14 as having "codified a tenant’s common law rights under the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment," but it does not state that this covenant (or the statutory covenant) is implied in every lease or tenancy at will under Massachusetts common law. The case concerns the fault standard for statutory quiet enjoyment claims and their relationship to the lead paint statute, not the scope of when or in what tenancies the covenant is implied. Thus it does not provide authority for the specific proposition asserted.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847 (1997).relevant_excerpt: General Laws c. 186, § 14, originally enacted in 1927, codified a tenant’s common law rights under the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment. St. 1927, c. 339, § 1. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 101-102 (1982). At common law, and as originally enacted by statute, the covenant of quiet enjoyment prohibited a landlord from wilful or intentional interference with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the leased premises.

Winchester v. O\u2019Brien, 266 Mass. 33.proposition: The statutory covenant is also implied in every lease and tenancy at will under Massachusetts common law.
Winchester v. O\u2019Brien, 266 Mass. 33.support_reasoning: The opinion does not discuss any statutory covenant, nor does it state that such a statutory covenant is implied in every lease or tenancy at will. Instead, it relies on common-law implications from the grant/lease (an implied promise that the landlord will not substantially impair the character and value of the premises) and on tort and nuisance principles. The court explicitly frames the case as involving an implied covenant for quiet enjoyment and wrongful interference, not a statutory covenant applicable to all leases and tenancies at will.
Winchester v. O\u2019Brien, 266 Mass. 33.relevant_excerpt: “The ‘grant of any thing carries an implication, that the grantee shall have all that is necessary to the enjoyment of the grant, so far as the grantor has power to give it.’ … The lease carried with it an implication that the lessors would refrain from acts voluntarily undertaken which substantially ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … The defendants contend that the bill is framed solely on a breach of an implied covenant for quiet enjoyment and cannot be maintained. … The bill is not based solely on breach of the implied covenant.”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: The statutory covenant is also implied in every lease and tenancy at will under Massachusetts common law.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 and the common‑law covenant of quiet enjoyment as applied to this public‑housing tenancy, but it does not state that a statutory covenant is implied in every lease or tenancy at will under Massachusetts common law. The court focuses on whether the landlord’s omissions can constitute a breach of the statutory quiet enjoyment covenant in this particular context; it does not announce a general rule that a statutory covenant is implied in all Massachusetts tenancies. Therefore, it does not support the broad proposition claimed.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 186, § 14, provides, in relevant part, that ‘any lessor or landlord who directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant’ shall be punished by a fine or imprisonment, and also shall be subject to liability to the tenant for damages arising from the interference. … The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold.”

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782 (1994)
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782.proposition: The statutory covenant is also implied in every lease and tenancy at will under Massachusetts common law.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 and references common-law quiet enjoyment, but it does not state that the statutory covenant is implied in every lease or tenancy at will as a matter of Massachusetts common law. Instead, it applies § 14 directly and relies on prior cases about common-law quiet enjoyment to interpret the statute’s fault standard. There is no language suggesting that the statutory covenant itself is implied into all leases apart from the statute, so the case does not support the claimed proposition.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782.relevant_excerpt: “Thomas claimed that conditions in her apartment violated the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See G. L. c. 186, § 14. … Decisions from this court and from the Appeals Court clearly support the imposition of civil liability under § 14 in circumstances like those present in this case. In Ianello v. Court Management Corp., 400 Mass. 321, 323 (1987), it was said that a landlord violates § 14 when his acts or omissions impair the value of the leased premises. See also Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 718 (1977) (addressing breach of covenant of quiet enjoyment at common law…).”

Kacin v. Town of Medford Hous. Auth., 67.raw_text: Kacin v. Town of Medford Hous. Auth., 67 Mass. App. Ct. 1110 (2006)
Kacin v. Town of Medford Hous. Auth., 67.proposition: The statutory covenant is also implied in every lease and tenancy at will under Massachusetts common law.

Rugen v. Ward, 57 Mass. App. Ct. 1105 (2.raw_text: Rugen v. Ward, 57 Mass. App. Ct. 1105 (2003)
Rugen v. Ward, 57 Mass. App. Ct. 1105 (2.proposition: The statutory covenant is also implied in every lease and tenancy at will under Massachusetts common law.

Cummings Props., LLC v. National Commun..raw_text: Cummings Props., LLC v. National Commun. Corp., 449 Mass. 490 (2007)
Cummings Props., LLC v. National Commun..proposition: The statutory covenant is also implied in every lease and tenancy at will under Massachusetts common law.
Cummings Props., LLC v. National Commun..case_name: Cummings Properties, LLC v. National Communications Corp.
Cummings Props., LLC v. National Commun..support_reasoning: The opinion is about the enforceability of a rent acceleration / liquidated damages clause in a commercial lease. It does not discuss the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment or any statutory covenant implied into leases or tenancies at will under Massachusetts common law. Because the decision never addresses implied covenants in leases or tenancies at will, it cannot be used as authority for the claimed proposition.
Cummings Props., LLC v. National Commun..relevant_excerpt: It is well settled that a contract provision clearly and reasonably establishing liquidated damages should be enforced so long as it is not so disproportionate to anticipated damages as to constitute a penalty. TAL Fin. Corp. v. CSC Consulting, Inc., 446 Mass. 422, 431 (2006), citing Kaplan v. Gray, 215 Mass. 269, 270-273 (1913). If, at the time the contract was made, actual damages were difficult to ascertain and the sum agreed on by the parties as liquidated damages represents a reasonable forecast of damages expected to occur in the event of a breach, it will usually be enforced.
